titleStmt.title: Speciall newes from the army at Warwicke since the fight: sent from a minister of good note, to an alderman here in London: wherein is related the names of such that are slain and taken prisoners of both sides: and also the comming of the Marquesse of Hartford towards Hereford with 2000. men, but made to retreate againe by the appearing of the Lord Stampford and his forces: also the funerall of Colonel Charls Essex at Warwick, his body being borne to the grave by the Lo: Mandevill, Lo: Brookes, and some 4. or 6. colonels: with other remarkable passages of truth touching that great battle, not yet printed, which will give great satisfaction to the reader. Also a most pious passage uttered by his Excellency to Master Marshall, upon their discourse of the battle.
titleStmt.author: J. B.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 11 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 4 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

Also a most pious passage uttered by his Excellency to Master Marshall, upon their discourse of the battle.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: SPECIALL NEWES FROM THE ARMY AT Warwicke ≈øince the Fight:
Sent From A Mini≈øter of good note, to an Alderman here in London:

p.hi: Wherein is related the names of ≈øuch that are ≈ølain and taken pri≈øoners of both ≈øides:

div.p: And al≈øo the comming of the Marque≈ø≈øe of Hartford towards Hereford with 2000. men, but made to Retreate againe by the appearing of the LORD Stampford and his Forces:
Al≈øo the Funerall of Colonel Charls E≈ø≈øex at Warwick, His Body being borne to the grave by the Lo: Mandevill, Lo: Brookes, and ≈øome 4. or 6. Colonels:

p.hi: With other remarkable Pa≈ø≈øages of truth touching that great Battle, not yet printed, which will give great ≈øatisfaction to the READER.

div.p: Al≈øo a mo≈øt pious pa≈ø≈øage uttered by his Excellency to Ma≈øter Mar≈øhall, upon their di≈øcour≈øe of the Battle.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Overton, at his Shop in Popes-Head Alley. Octob. 29. 1642.

div.head: Warwick, Octob. 27. 1642.

body.p:
WHat≈øoever was in Dr. Coxe his Letter to your ≈øon, I likewi≈øe affirme, and thereunto make ≈øome addition. The Earle of Lind≈øey I ≈øaw brought dead under his wounds, into Warwicke Ca≈øtle upon Tue≈øday night, the Lord John, brother to the Duke of Lenox, was ≈ølain in the fight. The Kings red Regiment of 12. hundred men, mo≈øt of them Gentlemen, were fir≈øt routed by my Lord Generals Lifeguard of Gentlemen, and then abundantly ≈ømitten downe by the Orange Coats, and Sir William Con≈øtable his blew Coats, one of who≈øe En≈øignes, Mr. Young by name, had the fir≈øt honour of taking the Kings Standard, which afterwards an hor≈øeman got into his hands, and rid away with it to the Lord Generall, who bravely flouri≈øhed it in the field, and then gave it his Secretary, Ma≈øter Chambers to keep, and how he lo≈øt it I know not. There are ≈ølaine on the Kings ≈øide at lea≈øt ten for one, though well nigh three parts of tho≈øe who are ≈ølaine on our ≈øide were Waggoners, Carters, and poore unarmed people that ≈øtood in the Reere to ≈øee the fight, ≈øome of them old men, women and Children, a poore piece of valour for ≈øuch a boa≈øting enemy. It is reported that Prince Rupert was ≈øo wi≈øe as not to come neare much danger, but in ≈øtead of fighting, ≈øpent his time in pillaging our Noble mens Waggons behinde our Army. We have many men ≈øoarely wounded, but it was more with flying, then fighting. The Earle of Bullingbrooke his ≈øon, alias, my Lord Sanit-Johns was the chiefe man that was ≈ølain on our ≈øide, who≈øe body is now embalmed, and prepared for
an interment: Colonell Charles E≈ø≈øex was buryed with the ≈øolemnity of a Souldier in a Church at Warwicke on Wedne≈øday (which was your Fa≈øt day, but by the command of his Excellency was our day of thankfulne≈ø≈øe) his Corps was borne to the grave by the Lord Mandevill, the Lord Brooke, and ≈øome foure or ≈øix other Colonels. On Munday the King ≈øent an Herauld of Armes to his Excellency, ≈øome ≈øay the me≈ø≈øage was to offer a generall pardon upon laying downe of Armes &c. And the an≈øwer, That the Parliament mu≈øt determine what in this ca≈øe ≈øhould be done, but I cannot confidently ≈øpeake this. When the left Wing of our Hor≈øe (which were mo≈øt of our hor≈øe which we chiefly relyed upon) fled, and likewi≈øe the Gunners which on that part of the Army ≈øhould have played upon the enemy, almo≈øt 5. Regiments of the foote on the right Wing fled ≈øoone after. The Lord Mandevils men would not ≈øtand the field, though his Lord≈øhip be≈øeeched them, yea, cudgelled them: no nor yet the Lord Whartons men: Sir William Fairefax his whole Regiment, as I heard, and all Colonell Chomley his Regiment, except ≈øome 80. of them, u≈øed their heeles. It is ≈øhrewdly ≈øu≈øpected that there was treachery in the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, for the Souldiers ≈øweare that their Commanders ran fir≈øt, and bid their ≈øouldiers run too, after farther examination I ≈øuppo≈øe you will heare more. Colonell Hollis his Regiment of red-Coates, under God did mo≈øt gallant ≈øervice, every one fighting like a Lion, with ≈øuch a glorious ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, that by the help of the Lord Brookes purple-Coats, they won the field, & crowned a mo≈øt bloody battle with an honourable victory: and yet I mu≈øt not forget to tell you that the Lord Roberts his red-Coats, and the Lord Sayes blew-Coats, together with part of Colonell Ballards gray-Coats, did good ≈øervice. In generall the right Wing of the hor≈øe, and the left wing of the foote bore the brunt of the day, and obtained the victory. If I ≈øhould relate how admirably the hand of Providence ordered our Artillery and Bullets for the de≈øtruction of the enemy, but how ≈øeldome or never almo≈øt we were hurt by theirs, you would ≈øtand and wonder: tho≈øe that rid mo≈øt gallantly among an hundred thou≈øand bullets, and faced, and charged the enemy; where fir≈øt his Excellency, the Lord of Bedford, Sir William Balfore, Sir John Meldrum, Commander of the Lord Say
his Regiment, Sir Philip Stapleton, Sir Arthur Ha≈ølerig, Sir Samuel Luke, Sergeant Mojor Hurny, Captaine Hunt though left all alone, the≈øe are ≈øome of tho≈øe which are chiefely ≈øpoken of for their valour; ≈øome of our Pri≈øoners now with the King, are Captaine Au≈øten, Captaine Scroope, Captaine Lydcot, two or three of my Lords guard.

The pre≈øent newes with us is, that London provides bravely, which we are glad of, and that the Counties Southward are all ready to a≈ø≈øi≈øt us, I hope it is true. The Kings Army are mad in pillaging ≈øince the fight, and now threaten Bambury; wee heare this day that the Earle of We≈øtmerland is taken at Northampton: You may a≈ø≈øure my Lord Maior that his ≈øonne is as well and cheerfull as ever, though he and I have lo≈øt three or foure pretious friends of our acquaintance in the fight, as namely one Ma≈øter Cardinall, Ma≈øter Michelthawrt, Ma≈øter Nel≈øon, Ma≈øter Elice, the fir≈øt is certainly ≈ølaine, the other three wee feare are ≈ølaine or taken pri≈øoners, for as yet wee cannot heare of them. The Marque≈ø≈øe of Hartford lately came towards Hereford with ≈øome 2000. men, but the Lord Stamford who lies there in Garri≈øon, by his very appearing, made him glad to recreate. Our Army is now refre≈øhing it ≈øelfe at Warwicke, what farther ≈øervice it ≈øhall be put to, or when we ≈øhall march againe wee know not; that which God hath already done by it, de≈øerves prai≈øe from England to perpetuall ages, e≈øpecially ≈øince the godly part of the Army have beene in≈øtrumentall in this noble ≈øervice. Ma≈øter William Sedgwicke of Farnham behaved him≈øelfe like a brave Commander in the Army. I be≈øeech you Sir if there be any thing new to you in this Letter, be plea≈øed to let my Lord Maior, and ≈øome ≈øpeciall friends, have a ≈øight of it, as Sergeant Major Skippon, &c. and it would be a charitable worke if ≈øome rich Citizen would drop the ≈øilver oyle of his pur≈øe into the wounds of the ≈øick and maimed ≈øouldiers who have ≈øo freely hazarded their lives for the Go≈øpell, for their bleedings move compa≈ø≈øion in him who really pre≈øents his humble re≈øpects to your beloved yoke-fellow, and is ever re≈øolved to bee

closer.signed: Your Wor≈øhips ≈øervant affectionately devoted. J. B.

div.p: COventry very nobly ≈øent in 18. loade of provi≈øion for the Army, and freely gave it; wee have taken about 30. of the Kings Waggons, with goods, Armes, &c. had I time to relate it, I could give you eight or ten particulars of the advantages which our enemy had, and the di≈øadvantages which wee had, the very knowledge whereof will make it appeare that the ≈øalvation of the la≈øt Sabboth was very glorious; if it may be u≈øefull, you may print this letter as an addition to that which I ≈øent to my Lord Maior, for I conceive you have many fal≈øe rumors, but what I write, you may be confident, for the maine is true.

Ma≈øter Henry Boys is ≈øafe at Warwicke, and becau≈øe Ma≈øter Sprat comes immediatly to London from his Excellency, he thinks it be≈øt to ≈øtay two or three dayes for ≈øome other newes, which he entreats your wor≈øhip to impart to the Committees.

One gallant pa≈ø≈øage of his Excellency I had almo≈øt forgot; it is truely worthy not onely to be knowne by all men, but unto his prai≈øe to be put into Characters of Gold. It was this, Ma≈øter Mar≈øhall was ≈øpeaking of the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of the battell, his excellency replyed twice together, that he never ≈øaw le≈ø≈øe of man in any thnig, nor more of God, which pious expre≈ø≈øion of a Generalls heart de≈øerves a due Emblazon of prai≈øe.

SInce I ≈øealed my Letter, I remember to tell you that Sir Edmund Varnee the Kings Standard-bearer is ≈ølaine; and generally all his be≈øt Commanders are either ≈ølaine or taken; but few are left with him, the Foot run away apace from their colours, ≈øo that of Foote and Hor≈øe both, his Maje≈øty hath not many thou≈øands left; the number of the ≈ølaine men on the Kings ≈øide betweene two and three thou≈øand, and our ≈øide is reputed to be not above 80. or 100. at mo≈øt upon the place of the fight, be≈øides what were ≈ølaine in the flight. Wee feare that Banbury is yeelded up, ≈øuch newes is ju≈øt now brought, ≈øo that to morrow his Excellency will march towards the King. Colonell Norris at Coventry hath taken eight of the Kings Waggons, one of which being opened hath Plate in in it, what are in the re≈øt we know not.
